citations.narrative:
Over the past four months, the lorikeet encounter has resulted in 14 occurrences where members of the public have been
injured. Upon review of the documented reports, 12 of the 14 injuries resulted in the skin being broken on either the
fingers or hands of the guest. Although the facility has continued to mitigate these incidents, these type of injuries
continue to recur.
Hands-on experiences with lorikeets have the potential to result in additional stress and harm to the patrons and birds if
the encounters cannot substantially mitigate aggression amongst the lorikeets and compliance of the guests handling the
birds.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Correct by June 17, 2024.

One opened bag of dried cranberries used as training enrichment for variable nonhuman primate species has expired.
This container was stored with the remaining edible enrichment items and discovered during the inspection. Feeding food
items beyond its expiration date prevents the facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld and
preserved. Food shall be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value
to maintain all animals in good health.
The facility corrected during the inspection.

One container of black pepper currently in use as an ingestible enrichment item for the giraffes, babirusa, and rhinoceros
has expired. The container was stored in the cabinet with the other enrichment items that are currently used for the
animals at the facility. Within this cabinet was a chart that outlined the use of each enrichment type, as well as a
statement referring to the expiration reminder stickers present on each item. Feeding food items beyond its expiration
date prevents the facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld and preserved. Food shall be wholesome,
palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain all animals in good health.
The facility corrected during the inspection.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Upon inspection, one Swan Goose was individually housed and unable to see or hear birds of their own or compatible
species. The inspector spoke with the attending veterinarian at the facility, who stated they did not consider the
neighboring avian species conspecific or compatible with its species-specific social needs. While the facility clarified that
the Swan Goose would only be singly-housed for about a week, the inspector explained that special considerations and
provisions should be provided for this duration.
Implementing enrichment protocols for special consideration categories ensure sufficient conditions are in place to
promote the psychological well-being of the impacted birds at the facility. Certain birds must be provided special attention
regarding enhancement of their environment, based on the needs of the individual species and/or individual bird, in
accordance with the instructions of the attending veterinarian. Special considerations must be included in the plan for
individually housed social species of birds that are unable to see or hear other birds of their own or compatible species.
Correct by May 25, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
Over the past four months, the lorikeet encounter has resulted in 14 occurrences where members of the public have been 
injured. Upon review of the documented reports, 12 of the 14 injuries resulted in the skin being broken on either the 
fingers or hands of the guest. Although the facility has continued to mitigate these incidents, these type of injuries 
continue to recur. 
Hands-on experiences with lorikeets have the potential to result in additional stress and harm to the patrons and birds if 
the encounters cannot substantially mitigate aggression amongst the lorikeets and compliance of the guests handling the 
birds.  
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public. 
 
Correct by June 17, 2024. 
3.82(a) 
   
Feeding. 
One opened bag of dried cranberries used as training enrichment for variable nonhuman primate species has expired. 
This container was stored with the remaining edible enrichment items and discovered during the inspection. Feeding food 
items beyond its expiration date prevents the facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld and 
preserved. Food shall be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value 
to maintain all animals in good health. 
 
The facility corrected during the inspection. 
3.129(a) 
   
Feeding. 
One container of black pepper currently in use as an ingestible enrichment item for the giraffes, babirusa, and rhinoceros 
has expired. The container was stored in the cabinet with the other enrichment items that are currently used for the

animals at the facility. Within this cabinet was a chart that outlined the use of each enrichment type, as well as a 
statement referring to the expiration reminder stickers present on each item. Feeding food items beyond its expiration 
date prevents the facility from ensuring that the nutritive value has been upheld and preserved. Food shall be wholesome, 
palatable, and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain all animals in good health. 
 
The facility corrected during the inspection. 
3.154(c)(4) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Upon inspection, one Swan Goose was individually housed and unable to see or hear birds of their own or compatible 
species. The inspector spoke with the attending veterinarian at the facility, who stated they did not consider the 
neighboring avian species conspecific or compatible with its species-specific social needs. While the facility clarified that 
the Swan Goose would only be singly-housed for about a week, the inspector explained that special considerations and 
provisions should be provided for this duration. 
Implementing enrichment protocols for special consideration categories ensure sufficient conditions are in place to 
promote the psychological well-being of the impacted birds at the facility. Certain birds must be provided special attention 
regarding enhancement of their environment, based on the needs of the individual species and/or individual bird, in 
accordance with the instructions of the attending veterinarian. Special considerations must be included in the plan for 
individually housed social species of birds that are unable to see or hear other birds of their own or compatible species. 
 
Correct by May 25, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
